description: From Middle English on, from Old English on, an (‚Äúon, upon, onto, in, into‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *ana (‚Äúon, at‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *h‚ÇÇen-. Cognate with North Frisian a (‚Äúon, in‚Äù), Saterland Frisian an (‚Äúon, at‚Äù), West Frisian oan (‚Äúon, at‚Äù), Dutch aan (‚Äúon, at, to‚Äù), Low German an (‚Äúon, at‚Äù), German an (‚Äúto, at, on‚Äù), Swedish √• (‚Äúon, at, in‚Äù), Faroese √° (‚Äúon, onto, in, at‚Äù), Icelandic √° (‚Äúon, in‚Äù), Gothic êå∞êåΩêå∞ (ana), Ancient Greek ·ºÄŒΩŒ¨ (an√°, ‚Äúup, upon‚Äù), Albanian n√´ (‚Äúin‚Äù); and from Old Norse upp √°: Danish p√•, Swedish p√•, Norwegian p√•, see upon.

entries.meaning: In the state of being active, functioning or operating.
examples: Antonym: off
All the lights are on, so they must be home.

entries.meaning: Performing according to schedule; taking place.
examples: Are we still on for tonight?
Is the show still on?
We had to ration our food because there was a war on.
That TV programme that you wanted to watch is on now.

entries.meaning: Fitted; covering; being worn.
examples: Your feet will soon warm up once your socks are on.
I was trying to drink out of the bottle while the top was still on!

entries.meaning: (postpositive) Of a stated part of something, oriented towards the viewer or other specified direction.
examples: The photograph shows the UFO side on.
edge on, side on, end on, face on

entries.meaning: (chiefly UK, informal, usually negative) Acceptable, appropriate.
examples: You can't do that; it's just not on.

entries.meaning: (informal) Destined, normally in the context of a challenge being accepted; involved, doomed.
examples: "Five bucks says the Cavs win tonight." ‚Äï"You're on!"
Mike just threw coffee onto Paul's lap. It's on now.

entries.meaning: (baseball, informal) Having reached a base as a runner and being positioned there, awaiting further action from a subsequent batter.
(cricket) Within the half of the field on the same side as the batsman's legs; the left side for a right-handed batsman.
examples: Synonym: leg; Antonym: off
The captain moved two fielders to the on side.
Ponsonby-Smythe hit a thumping on drive.

entries.meaning: (acting, drama, role-playing games) Acting in character.
(euphemistic) Menstruating.

adverbs.description: on (not comparable) For idiomatic meanings of phrasal verbs, such as carry on, hang on, have on, try on, etc., please see the individual entries.

entries.meaning: To an operating state.
examples: turn the television on

entries.meaning: So as to cover or be fitted.
examples: The lid wasn't screwed on properly.
Put on your hat and gloves.

entries.meaning: Along, forwards (continuing an action).
examples: drive on, rock on

entries.meaning: In continuation, at length.
examples: and so on
He rambled on and on.

entries.meaning: (obsolete in the US) Later.
examples: Ten years on, nothing had changed in the village.

entries.meaning: Of betting odds, denoting a better-than-even chance. See also odds-on.
examples: Antonym: against
That horse is twenty-to-one on, so you need to stake twenty pounds just to win one pound.

entries.meaning: Positioned at the upper surface of, touching from above.
examples: A vase of flowers stood on the table.
Please lie down on the couch.
The parrot was sitting on Jim's shoulder.

entries.meaning: Positioned at or resting against the outer surface of; attached to.
examples: He had a scar on the side of his face.
There is a dirty smudge on this window.
The painting hangs on the wall.
The fruit ripened on the trees.

entries.meaning: Expressing figurative placement or attachment.
examples: All of the responsibility is on him.
I put a bet on the winning horse.

entries.meaning: Denoting performance or action by contact with the surface, upper part, or outside of anything; hence, by means of; with.
examples: to play on a violin or piano

entries.meaning: At or in (a certain region or location).
examples: The lighthouse that you can see is on the mainland.
The suspect is thought to still be on the campus.

entries.meaning: Near; adjacent to; alongside.
examples: The fleet is on the American coast.
Croton-on-Hudson, Rostov-on-Don, Southend-on-Sea

entries.meaning: Supported by (the specified part of itself).
examples: A table can't stand on two legs.
After resting on his elbows, he stood on his toes, then walked on his heels.

entries.meaning: So as to impart force to.
examples: tug on the rope; push hard on the door

entries.meaning: So as to impact; against.
examples: I stubbed my toe on an old tree stump.

entries.meaning: Covering.
examples: He wore old shoes on his feet.

entries.meaning: (with certain modes of transport, especially public transport) Inside (a vehicle) for the purpose of travelling.
examples: on a bus, on a train, on a plane

entries.meaning: At the date of.
examples: Born on the 4th of July.

entries.meaning: Some time during the day of.
examples: On Sunday I'm busy. I'll see you on Monday.
Can I see you on a different day?

entries.meaning: At a given time after the start of something; at.
examples: Smith scored again on twelve minutes, doubling Mudchester Rovers' lead.

entries.meaning: Dealing with the subject of; about; concerning.
examples: I was reading a book on history.
The city hosted the World Summit on the Information Society
I have no opinion on this subject.

entries.meaning: (informal) In the possession of.
examples: I haven't got any money on me.

entries.meaning: Because of, or due to.
examples: to arrest someone on suspicion of bribery
to contact someone on a hunch

entries.meaning: Upon; at the time of (and often because of).
examples: On Jack's entry, William got up to leave.
On the addition of ammonia, a chemical reaction begins.

entries.meaning: Paid for by.
examples: The drinks are on me tonight, boys.
The meal is on the house.
I paid for the airfare and meals for my family, but the hotel room was on the company.

entries.meaning: Indicating a means or medium.
examples: I saw it on television.
Can't you see I'm on the phone?
My favorite shows are on BBC America.
The Beatles' appearance on the Ed Sullivan Show is on YouTube.
The film was released on DVD.

entries.meaning: Indicating the target of, or thing affected by, an event or action.
examples: They planned an attack on London.
The soldiers mutinied and turned their guns on their officers.
Her words made a lasting impression on my mind.
What will be the effect on morale?

entries.meaning: Toward; for; indicating the object of an emotion.
examples: Have pity or compassion on him.

entries.meaning: (especially Ireland) Indicating the person experiencing an emotion, cold, thirst, hunger, etc.
Indicating a means of subsistence.
examples: They lived on ten dollars a week.
The dog survived three weeks on rainwater.

entries.meaning: Engaged in or occupied with (an action or activity).
examples: He's on his lunch break.
I'm on nights all this week.
on vacation; on holiday; on the job; on the fiddle

entries.meaning: Regularly taking (a drug).
examples: You've been on these antidepressants far too long.
He's acting so strangely, I think he must be on something.

entries.meaning: Under the influence of (a drug).
examples: He's acting crazy because he's on crack right now.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Having identical domain and codomain.
examples: a function on

entries.meaning:
(mathematics) Having 
  
    
      
        
          V
          
            n
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle V^{n}}
  
 as domain and V as codomain, for some set V and integer n.
examples: an operator on

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Generated by.
examples: the free group on four letters

entries.meaning: In addition to; besides; indicating multiplication or succession in a series.
examples: heaps on heaps of food
mischief on mischief; loss on loss

entries.meaning: (obsolete, regional) of
Indicating dependence or reliance.
examples: I depended on them for assistance.
He will promise on certain conditions.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) At the peril of, or for the safety of.
Serving as a member of.
examples: He is on the jury; I am on the committee.

entries.meaning: By virtue of; with the pledge of.
examples: He affirmed or promised on his word, or on his honour.

entries.meaning: To the account or detriment of; denoting imprecation or invocation, or coming to, falling, or resting upon.
examples: On us be all the blame.
A curse on him!
Please don't tell on her and get her in trouble.
He turned on her and has been her enemy ever since.
He went all honest on me, making me listen to his confession.

entries.meaning: (especially when numbers of combatants or competitors are specified) Against; in opposition to.
examples: The fight was three on one, and he never stood a chance.

verbs.description: on (third-person singular simple present ons, present participle oning or onning, simple past and past participle oned or onned)

entries.meaning: (Singapore, Philippines, Malaysia, transitive, colloquial) To switch on.
examples: Can you on the light?
Synonym: turn on

description: From Old Norse √≥n, √°n (‚Äúwithout‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *ƒìnu, *ƒìno, *ino (‚Äúwithout‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *·∏ónu (‚Äúwithout‚Äù). Cognate with North Frisian on (‚Äúwithout‚Äù), Middle Dutch an, on (‚Äúwithout‚Äù), Middle Low German ƒÅne (‚Äúwithout‚Äù), German ohne (‚Äúwithout‚Äù), Gothic êåπêåΩêåø (inu, ‚Äúwithout, except‚Äù), Ancient Greek ·ºÑŒΩŒµœÖ (√°neu, ‚Äúwithout‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, Scotland) Without.
In the Japanese language, a pronunciation, or reading, of a kanji character that was originally based on the character's pronunciation in Chinese, contrasted with kun.
examples: Most kanji have two kinds of reading, called "on" and "kun".
